abstract.p: We report a case of right coronary sinus of Valsalva aneurysm (SVA) with rupture into the right ventricle in a 23-year-old man. The problem was successfully managed with surgical closure of both ruptured SVA and the ventricular defect with cardiopulmonary bypass through median sternotomy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sinus of Valsalva aneurysms (SVAs) are rare congenital or acquired cardiac anomalies, most commonly involving the right or noncoronary sinuses.1 Congenital SVAs account for 0.5% to 3% of all congenital cardiac defects. In addition, inflammatory diseases, such as syphilis, tuberculosis, endocarditis, and Behçet disease, as well as traumatic events and connective tissue disorders, such as Marfan syndrome, can be the cause of this anomaly.2 Rupture of an SVA requires definitive repair because of progressive left-to-right shunt leading to right heart failure. The treatment of choice is a surgical approach, although transcatheter occlusion has occasionally been shown to be an alternative.3

We report about a 23-year-old man who was referred for evaluation of a heart murmur detected recently during a routine checkup. The patient had an unsuspicious medical history, without previous infection, trauma, or connective tissue disease. He was completely asymptomatic while resting or exercising. Physical examination revealed a continuous 3/6 systolic–diastolic precordial murmur but was otherwise unremarkable. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a left-to-right shunt that originated from the aortic root, with a slightly enlarged right atrium and ventricle. Transesophageal echocardiography confirmed a right coronary SVA with rupture into the right ventricle (Figure 1).

caption.p: Transthoracic echocardiography confirming right coronary sinus of Valsalva aneurysm with rupture (arrow) into the right ventricle. RA indicates right atrium; RV, right ventricle; AV, aortic valve.

sec.p: Angiography confirmed the findings of a ruptured SVA into the right ventricle (Figure 2 ), with catheterization data revealing a left-to-right shunt with pulmonary-to-systemic flow ratio (Qp:Qs) of 1.5:1. The patient was scheduled for an urgent surgical repair of the ruptured aneurysm.

caption.p: Cardiac catheterization with aortic root angiography confirming the findings of a ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm into the right ventricle (arrow).

sec.p: The patient was operated through median sternotomy using standard cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) with moderate hypothermia and cold crystalloid cardioplegia for myocardial preservation. The right coronary sinus of Valsalva was dilated. The aortic orifice of the ruptured sinus of Valsalva was exposed through a transverse aortotomy. The defect in the sinus, at the hinge point of the right coronary leaflet (RCL) valve, measured 1 × 1 cm (Figure 3). It was closed with a double mattress suture line of 5/0 polyprolene (Figure 4). The defect on the ventricular side was exposed through a right ventriculotomy and was closed with a separate autologous pericardial patch using continuous suture of 5/0 polyprolene (Figure 5). We think that the rupture of the SVA was into a congenital ventricular septal defect. The patient made an uneventful recovery. Postoperative echocardiography confirmed complete closure of both defects, without any significant aortic valve regurgitation and patient remained in sinus rhythm.

caption.p: The right coronary leaflet (RCL) of the aortic valve. The defect in the sinus, at the hinge point of the valve leaflet (RCL), measured 1 × 1 cm.
The aortic orifice of the ruptured sinus of Valsalva was closed by double mattress suture line with 5/0 polyprolene.
The defect on the right ventricular side was exposed through a right ventriculotomy and was closed with a separate autologous pericardial patch using continuous suture 5/0 polyprolene.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We here report a rare case of a ruptured right coronary SVA into the right ventricle, which resulted in an increased left-to-right shunt with the need for urgent definitive repair. Sinus of Valsalva aneurysms are rare congenital or acquired cardiac anomalies, most commonly involving the right or noncoronary sinuses. Congenital SVAs account for about 0.5% to 3% of all congenital cardiac defects. In addition, inflammatory diseases, such as syphilis, tuberculosis, endocarditis, and Behçet disease, as well as traumatic events and connective tissue disorders, such as Marfan syndrome, can be the cause of this anomaly.

The clinical significance and manifestation of ruptured SVAs depend on their anatomic location and the amount of flow through the abnormal communication.2–4 Determination of the specific etiology of SVA may be difficult and various pathologic processes may affect the development. Atherosclerotic degenerative processes or traumatic or infective diseases are usually the cause for acquired SVAs, and only 1% to 10% of SVAs originate in the left or right coronary sinus.3,4

Although nonruptured SVAs remain silent, they may extend and cause more complicated and severe symptoms requiring more extensive surgical corrections.3 The treatment of choice should be a surgical approach because of the direct approach to each end of the defect and the ability to either primarily close or patch the ends of the defect without significant prosthetic material. The very low morbidity and mortality of operative intervention should continue to lend favor of this approach, even in asymptomatic patients, to prevent poor prognosis.
